title: Beginner Cargo Transportation Processes
headline: Characteristics of break bulk cargo, developing proper stowage plans and containerization are covered in this course.
description: This free online introductory course on cargo transportation processes teaches you about the characteristics of break bulk cargo, as well how to develop a proper stowage plan. You will learn about loading and discharging operations in shipping, as well as the information that is exchanged in the pre-arrival checklist. Start this course today to also improve your understanding of the process of containerization, as well as liner shipping services.
courseDescription:
Introduction to Cargo Transportation Processes is a free online course that begins by introducing you to the characteristics of break bulk cargo, as well demonstrating how to develop a proper stowage plan. It will also familiarize you with the actions of the shipper when securing cargo, as well as the importance of ventilation in cargo transportation. The functions of petroleum logistics, as well as the importance of the supply chain in the oil industry, will also be covered in the material.

Next, this course explains the four types of shipping terms regulated by Incoterms (the global rules of trade for the sale of goods), as well as choke points in oil transportation. You will learn about loading and discharging operations in shipping, as well as the vital information that is exchanged in the pre-arrival checklist. This course will teach you about the metrics of cargo measurements, as well as how temperature and volume values are corrected.

Furthermore, you will get familiar with container systems as an essential part of maritime logistics, as well as the process of ‘containerization’. Learn about some liner service strategies and how they are applied, as well as the multi-trade strategies used in shipping today. This free online course will be of great use to students and researchers of modern maritime logistics, and anyone with an interest in the processes carried out during and after cargo transportation.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Outline the characteristics of the breakbulk cargo. 
    • Explain how to develop a proper stowage plan. 
    • Identify the actions of the actions by the shipper when securing cargo. 
    • Analyze the process of ventilation in cargo transportation.
    • Outline the requirements for different types of project cargo and heavy cargo units.
  • Introduction 
  • Breakbulk cargo is in many ways, the most complex type of ocean born cargo to handle. The reason can be explained in one word: variety. Breakbulk cargo by definition is shipped in an infinite variety of sizes, dimensions, weights. It can take the form of pallets, bales, coils, rolls, bundles, heavy lift, and even containers. Ensuring that the commodity is safely loaded and offloaded from the ship is a complex undertaking requiring specialized knowledge and experience.

    There are certain key characteristics that define all breakbulk cargo. Since each piece of breakbulk cargo is unique, the process of finding a proper place for it aboard the ship, fitting other cargo around it, and determining a price to charge the shipper, all are derived from these key characteristics. The characteristics primarily relate to dimension and weight.

    Handling, stowage, securing, and care during transit are the other challenges faced in the transportation of breakbulk cargo. Not all ports are equipped to handle breakbulk cargoes. Terminal operations and the stevedoring of breakbulk cargo require specialized skills.

    Dedicated handling gear and equipment are required for breakbulk cargo. Meticulous advanced planning and coordination among the vessel crew, longshore labour and others involved in handling such as truckers and railroad workers are essential to ensure the successful transfer of breakbulk cargo from the shore to the ship and back again.

  • Ventilation
  • When cargo is placed in the hold of a ship, it is in an enclosed space. Like any enclosed space, the atmosphere is denied fresh air. The environment in the hold undergoes a change in temperature or atmospheric composition during the voyage, potentially damaging the cargo and creating unsafe conditions if remedial steps are not taken. For example, when a ship sails from a cold climate into a warm climate, the cold steel of the ship’s structure come in contact with warm air, creating condensation in the hold.

    Cargoes including newsprint or foodstuffs stand to be damaged by excessive moisture in the hold. In another example, cargoes such as grains and natural fibres emit heat when stored in an enclosed space including a ship’s cargo hold. This can result in overheating, deterioration, and in extreme cases, spontaneous combustion of the cargo.

    The action to be taken to avoid these hazards is through proper ventilation. Ventilation is the process by which air from the outside is intentionally introduced into an enclosed space to replace the air that is stale, moist, poisonous or explosive. This may be accomplished by either natural or mechanical means. In most ships, trunkways for the passage of air connect the cargo spaces with the outside. In the case of mechanical or forced ventilation, fans are fitted in the trunkways.

    An effective practice to cleanse the environment in the hold is to run one fan in the ventilate direction and the other in the exhaust direction. This clears the air faster but care should be taken to ensure that any air entering a cargo compartment is comparatively dry. Some cargo ventilation systems are fitted with humidity sensors and only permit air intake when the ambient humidity is low or after processing it through a dehumidifier. Using a dehumidifier is particularly beneficial when carrying sensitive cargoes such as newsprint and forest products.

Ventilation is the process by which air from the outside is intentionally introduced into an enclosed space to replace the air that is stale, moist, poisonous or explosive. This may be accomplished by either natural or mechanical means. In most ships, trunkways for the passage of air connect the cargo spaces with the outside. In the case of mechanical or forced ventilation, fans are fitted in the trunkways.

    An effective practice to cleanse the environment in the hold is to run one fan in the ventilate direction and the other in the exhaust direction. This clears the air faster but care should be taken to ensure that any air entering a cargo compartment is comparatively dry. Some cargo ventilation systems are fitted with humidity sensors and only permit air intake when the ambient humidity is low or after processing it through a dehumidifier. Using a dehumidifier is particularly beneficial when carrying sensitive cargoes such as newsprint and forest products.
  • Ventilation
  • When cargo is placed in the hold of a ship, it is in an enclosed space. Like any enclosed space, the atmosphere is denied fresh air. The environment in the hold undergoes a change in temperature or atmospheric composition during the voyage, potentially damaging the cargo and creating unsafe conditions if remedial steps are not taken. For example, when a ship sails from a cold climate into a warm climate, the cold steel of the ship’s structure come in contact with warm air, creating condensation in the hold.

    Cargoes including newsprint or foodstuffs stand to be damaged by excessive moisture in the hold. In another example, cargoes such as grains and natural fibres emit heat when stored in an enclosed space including a ship’s cargo hold. This can result in overheating, deterioration, and in extreme cases, spontaneous combustion of the cargo.

    The action to be taken to avoid these hazards is through proper ventilation. Ventilation is the process by which air from the outside is intentionally introduced into an enclosed space to replace the air that is stale, moist, poisonous or explosive.   • Lesson Summary
    • Breakbulk cargo is in many ways, the most complex type of ocean born cargo to handle.
    • Breakbulk cargo by definition is shipped in an infinite variety of sizes, dimensions, weights. It can take the form of pallets, bales, coils, rolls, bundles, heavy lift, and even containers.
    • Stowage refers to the process of loading the cargo aboard ship and securing it to withstand the rigours of sea transport.
    • The stowage plan is a master blueprint of where and how cargo is to be stowed aboard the ship. It should take into consideration several factors, including the weights and dimensions of each individual piece of cargo, any special requirements of the cargo, and the port of discharge.
    • Cargo securing is a science in itself, taking into consideration the various forces exerted on each piece of cargo whilst aboard a ship at sea.
    • The securing gear used must be tested and certified prior to use. 
    • When cargo is placed in the hold of a ship, it is in an enclosed space. Like any enclosed space, the atmosphere is denied fresh air. The environment in the hold undergoes a change in temperature or atmospheric composition during the voyage, potentially damaging the cargo and creating unsafe conditions if remedial steps are not taken.
    • Heavy Lift cargoes require specialized cargo-handling equipment fitted on the ship.
    • Project cargo handling is a specialized undertaking due to the oversized nature of cargo, complex handling involved, transportation and often inaccessibility of the project site. Setting up a project involves extensive planning and coordination with different stakeholders and service providers.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Outline all the functions of petroleum logistics. 
    • Explain the importance of the supply chain in the oil industry.
    • Identify the four types of shipping terms regulated by INCOTERMS. 
    • Analyze different choke points in oil transportation. 
    • Discuss how petroleum logistics has changed on a global scale. 
  • Steps Involved in Petroleum Logistics
  • Petroleum logistics comprises all functions or processes (storage, inventory, transportation and the flow of information) involved in the movement of petroleum and its refined products from the origin (whether it be an oil rig, a platform, or a refinery) to destination. There are a number of steps involved in the movement of petroleum from either offshore to the refinery or from the refinery to the port of import.

  • Transportation of Oil
  • The Transfer of oil from one country to another is a very large task. Billions of barrels of oil a day are shipped in Oil Tankers to various destinations all over the world. There are many different shipping routes, but there are eight major transit chokepoints which deal with the most traffic of oil tankers and are areas of high risk for something to go wrong with the oil transfer. These are huge security concerns and cause a sharp rise in energy price in case something goes wrong at those points.

    World chokepoints for maritime transit of oil are a critical part of global energy security. About 61% of the world's petroleum and other liquids production moved on maritime routes in 2015. The Strait of Hormuz and the Strait of Malacca are the world's most important strategic chokepoints by volume of oil transit. The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) defines world oil chokepoints as narrow channels along widely used global sea routes, some so narrow that restrictions are placed on the size of the vessel that can navigate through them. Chokepoints are a critical part of global energy security because of the high volume of petroleum and other liquids transported through their narrow straits.
    • In 2015, total world petroleum and other liquids supply was about 96.7 million barrels per day (b/d)
    • EIA estimates that about 61% that amount (58.9 million b/d) travelled via seaborne trade
    • Oil tankers accounted for almost 28% of the world’s shipping by deadweight tonnage in 2016 (UNCTAD)

  • Transportation of Oil
  • The Transfer of oil from one country to another is a very large task. Billions of barrels of oil a day are shipped in Oil Tankers to various destinations all over the world. There are many different shipping routes, but there are eight major transit chokepoints which deal with the most traffic of oil tankers and are areas of high risk for something to go wrong with the oil transfer. These are huge security concerns and cause a sharp rise in energy price in case something goes wrong at those points.

    World chokepoints for maritime transit of oil are a critical part of global energy security. About 61% of the world's petroleum and other liquids production moved on maritime routes in 2015. The Strait of Hormuz and the Strait of Malacca are the world's most important strategic chokepoints by volume of oil transit. The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) defines world oil chokepoints as narrow channels along widely used global sea routes, some so narrow that restrictions are placed on the size of the vessel that can navigate through them. Chokepoints are a critical part of global energy security because of the high volume of petroleum and other liquids transported through their narrow straits.

    • EIA estimates that about 61% that amount (58.9 million b/d) travelled via seaborne trade
    • Oil tankers accounted for almost 28% of the world’s shipping by deadweight tonnage in 2016 (UNCTAD)

    • Cargo Operation - Oil tanker
      Carrying out cargo operations on an oil tanker involves many complexities and hence it has to be carefully planned special consideration to safety. This topic will familiarize you with the fundamental aspects of different cargo operations on an oil tanker.

      There are many hazards involved in the daily operations on an oil tanker. All prescribed safety procedures and checklists must be followed to ensure a safe working atmosphere.

      One has to be fully aware of the hazards of the particular ship type and also the cargo carried. The Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) and other relevant information should be readily available for reference. The crew should familiarize themselves with the relevant MSDS before participating in any operation involving that substance.

      Oil cargo is usually pumped into the ship’s tanks using shore pumps and discharged using ship’s pumps. The cargo is carried in fully closed tanks with inert gas filling the space above the liquid if the flashpoint is less than 60°C.

The Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) and other relevant information should be readily available for reference. The crew should familiarize themselves with the relevant MSDS before participating in any operation involving that substance.

      Oil cargo is usually pumped into the ship’s tanks using shore pumps and discharged using ship’s pumps. The cargo is carried in fully closed tanks with inert gas filling the space above the liquid if the flashpoint is less than 60°C.
    • Preparation Before Loading
      Utmost diligence is required in planning the operations beforehand, with high regard for safety. The following are some of the important steps in repairing the vessel for loading oil cargo. The atmosphere in the cargo tanks must be checked for oxygen content less than 8%. Inerting should be carried out to reduce the oxygen content if it is found to be 8% or more. This 8% is prescribed by the IMO and the vessel will not be permitted to load otherwise.

      A detailed cargo plan is prepared by the Chief Officer prior to arrival at the load port. The plan must be posted at the Cargo Control Room (CCR) and the crew briefed on its contents. It should be distributed the personnel directly involved in the operation. They must sign to confirm that they have read and understood the plan.

      The Chief Officer also prepares a watch schedule for the crew and the officers-in-charge. Prior to commencing the loading, the Chief Officer conducts a cargo safety meeting with the concerned crew and officers. The ballast pumps must be tested and in all readiness when arriving at a load port.

      The appropriate checklists must be completed at each step in preparation as well as loading. These checklists must be signed and retained for future verification. Some checklists and permits will require the approval of the Master. The Duty Officer or the Chief Officer must be present at the Manifold while connecting the cargo transfer hose or arm.

      The appropriate checklists must be completed at each step in preparation as well as loading. These checklists must be signed and retained for future verification. Some checklists and permits will require the approval of the Master. The Duty Officer or the Chief Officer must be present at the Manifold while connecting the cargo transfer hose or arm.

  • Direct Line System
  • This is the simplest type of pipeline system which uses fewer valves than the others. It takes oil directly from the tank to the pump and so reduces friction. 

    This has an effect of increasing the rate of discharge, at the same time improving the tank suction. 

    It is cheaper to install and maintain than the ring main system because there is less pipeline length and with fewer valves less likelihood of malfunction. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • However, the layout is not as versatile as a ring main system and problems in the event of faulty valves or leaking pipelines could prove more difficult to circumvent. Also, the washing is more difficult since there is no circular system and the washings must be flushed into the tanks.

  • Bottom Lines
  • Cargo lines in tankers could differ a bit from one vessel to the other. But a generalisation is possible using a typical tanker pipeline layout diagram. This topic contains those diagrams and descriptions.

    Let us describe traditional piping on a crude oil tanker, and start with the cargo tank’s bottom lines. 

    The vessel is fitted with 4 centre tanks and 5 pairs of wing tanks for cargo.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The cargo main lines are located in the vessel’s centre tanks. With the term “bottom lines” we understand that the location of these lines will be on the bottom of the vessel, usually supported about 1 - 2m above the vessel’s bottom. Crossover valves, two valves on each crossover, connect the bottom lines to each other. When carrying more than one grade, two-valve segregation complies with the regulations in force.

    The figure above shows that, from the bottom lines, there are lines, which lead to each cargo tank. These lines end on the cargo tanks suction bell mouth. Each bottom line serves its own set of cargo tanks; for example, bottom line no.1 serves centre tank 1 and wing tanks 5 port/stbd. Bottom line no.2 serves wing tanks 1 port/stbd and centre tank 4. Bottom line no. 3 serves wing tanks 2 port/stbd, centre tank 3 and wing tank 6 port/stbd.
  • Bottom Lines
  • Cargo lines in tankers could differ a bit from one vessel to the other. But a generalisation is possible using a typical tanker pipeline layout diagram. This topic contains those diagrams and descriptions.

    Let us describe traditional piping on a crude oil tanker, and start with the cargo tank’s bottom lines. 

    The vessel is fitted with 4 centre tanks and 5 pairs of wing tanks for cargo.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The cargo main lines are located in the vessel’s centre tanks. With the term “bottom lines” we understand that the location of these lines will be on the bottom of the vessel, usually supported about 1 - 2m above the vessel’s bottom. Crossover valves, two valves on each crossover, connect the bottom lines to each other. When carrying more than one grade, two-valve segregation complies with the regulations in force.

    The figure above shows that, from the bottom lines, there are lines, which lead to each cargo tank. These lines end on the cargo tanks suction bell mouth. Each bottom line serves its own set of cargo tanks; for example, bottom line no.1 serves centre tank 1 and wing tanks 5 port/stbd. Bottom line no.2 serves wing tanks 1 port/stbd and centre tank 4. Bottom line no. 3 serves wing tanks 2 port/stbd, centre tank 3 and wing tank 6 port/stbd.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Petroleum logistics comprises all functions or processes (storage, inventory, transportation and the flow of information) involved in the movement of petroleum and its refined products from the origin (whether it be an oil rig, a platform, or a refinery) to destination.
    • A typical oil tanker shipment involves the following activities:
      - Contracts are signed and a ship is chartered. The chartering agreement (contract) may be for a voyage charter, a time charter, or a bareboat charter
      - Once the ship is nominated, the ship’s captain and other parties involved are advised of all details and the ship tenders its notice of readiness upon arrival at the load port
      - The ship will then proceed to the load port and load the cargo; upon completion of cargo work, the required documents are prepared and signed
      - The ship will then sail to the destination port and discharge the cargo to the consignee after completion of all necessary paperwork
    • The oil industry supply chain contains eight different stages from upstream exploration to downstream distribution and marketing.
    • Four types of shipping terms regulated by INCOTERMS are:
      - FAS – Free Alongside Ship
      - FOB – Free onboard
      - CFR – Cost and Freight
      - CIF – Cost, Insurance and Freight
    • The Oil and Gas cargoes are most dangerous to handle and are most often the primary cause of environmental and human disasters when accidents happen. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Outline the loading in discharging operations in shipping. 
    • Identify the information exchanged in the pre-arrival checklist. 
    • Analyze the factors used to determine the initial, maximum and topping off rates.
    • Discuss the precautions used to alleviate the effects of loading a hot cargo.
    • Explain various metrics of cargo measurements. 
    • Explain how temperature and volume values are corrected. 
  • Pre-Arrival Checklist
  • Keeping in view of maritime logistic students, the process of a tanker ship loading and discharging operation is kept simple and limited and includes the cargo measurement portion which is an important part of on-board handing over of the consignment from ship to shore and vice-versa.

    The tanker pre-arrival check list is an exchange of essential information between the tanker and the terminal for the safe conduct of loading or discharging operations. The information exchanged will contain the following:
    • Vessel information – (name, IMO number, drafts, displacement, cargo quantity etc.)
    • Type of cargo
    • Maximum draft expected during port stay
    • Any defects to hull, machinery or equipment that could adversely affect safe operations or delay commencement of cargo handling
    • If fitted with an inert gas system, confirmation that the ship’s tanks are in an inert condition and the system is fully operational
    • Any requirement for tank cleaning and/or gas freeing
    • Whether crude oil washing is to be employed and, if so, confirmation that the pre-arrival check-list has been satisfactorily completed
    • Ship’s manifold details, including type, size, number, the distance between centres of connections to be presented. Also, products to be handled at each manifold numbered from forward
    • Advance information on proposed cargo handling operations, including grades, sequence, quantities and rate restrictions
    • Information, as required, on quantity and nature of slops and dirty ballast and of any contamination by chemical additives. Such information should include identification of any toxic components, such as hydrogen sulphide and benzene
    • Quantities and specifications of bunkers required, if applicable

    The tanker pre-arrival check list is an exchange of essential information between the tanker and the terminal for the safe conduct of loading or discharging operations. The information exchanged will contain the following:
    • Vessel information – (name, IMO number, drafts, displacement, cargo quantity etc.)
    • Type of cargo
    • Maximum draft expected during port stay
    • Any defects to hull, machinery or equipment that could adversely affect safe operations or delay commencement of cargo handling
    • If fitted with an inert gas system, confirmation that the ship’s tanks are in an inert condition and the system is fully operational
    • Any requirement for tank cleaning and/or gas freeing
    • Whether crude oil washing is to be employed and, if so, confirmation that the pre-arrival check-list has been satisfactorily completed
    • Ship’s manifold details, including type, size, number, the distance between centres of connections to be presented. Also, products to be handled at each manifold numbered from forward
    • Advance information on proposed cargo handling operations, including grades, sequence, quantities and rate restrictions
    • Information, as required, on quantity and nature of slops and dirty ballast and of any contamination by chemical additives. Such information should include identification of any toxic components, such as hydrogen sulphide and benzene
    • Quantities and specifications of bunkers required, if applicable

  • Units of Measurements
  • An oil volume can only be measured at its prevailing temperature and it, therefore, follows that the standard volume must usually be calculated. Unfortunately, different countries have different standard (reference) temperatures. Generally, the reference temperatures are:

    In Eastern Bloc, Brazil 20 deg C;
    In Western Europe 15 deg C;
    In the USA 60 deg F.

    The situation is further confused in that there are primarily two volumetric units, which are: In metric countries the cubic meter (m3)
    In non-metric countries the barrel (Bbl).

    Combining a statement of volume with a statement of the reference temperature yields the following measurement systems:

    In Eastern Bloc, Brazil m3 at 20 deg C;
    In Western Europe m3 at 15 deg C;
    In the USA US Bbl at 60 deg F.

    It is customary to refer to volumes at the reference temperature as Standard Volumes e.g US barrels at 60 deg F
    For cubic meters at 15 deg C

  • Calculation Procedures
  • Density or API is provided by the terminal or surveyor in the load ports and what is used will be dependent on the region/port of loading. For example, in the USA / Canada, Persian Gulf, API usage is prevalent, while in Europe and Asia we use Density at 15oC.

    ASTM Tables

    TABLE 5 & 6 - FOR API, 60^\circ \text{F}
    Generalized Crude Oils (Tables 5A & 6A)
    Generalized Products (Tables 5B and 6B)

    TABLE 23 & 24 - FOR RELATIVE DENSITY, ^\circ \text{F}, 60^\circ \text{F}
    Generalized Crude Oils (Tables 23A & 24A)

  • Lesson Summary
    • The process of a tanker ship loading and discharging operation is kept simple and limited and includes the cargo measurement portion which is an important part of on-board handing over of the consignment from ship to shore and vice-versa.
    • The tanker pre-arrival checklist is an exchange of essential information between the tanker and the terminal for the safe conduct of loading or discharging operations.
    • Loading is commenced at a slow rate first filling the lines and not allowing static generation. The backpressure at the manifold is closely monitored. 
    • As per the Charterer’s instructions, the Chief Officer must record the water content in the cargo during the voyage in calm waters if required. 
    • Cargo heating should be done as per charterer’s instructions if required. The Chief Officer monitors the temperature of the cargo and liaises with the Chief Engineer for the maintenance of the cargo heating system.
    • A Powered Emergency Release Coupling (PERC) is a hydraulically operated device to provide quick disconnection of a marine loading arm in an emergency, or when the operating envelope of a loading arm is exceeded.
    • The Emergency Release System (ERS) valves above and below the Emergency Release Coupling (ERC) are hydraulically or mechanically interlocked to ensure they close fully prior to ERC operation.
    • The equipment and procedure used for measuring temperature should conform as closely as possible to the recommendations of the American Petroleum Institute (API) and the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM). The calculated volume error can be up to 0.1% for an error of 1°C in the tank temperature. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain container systems as an essential part of maritime logistics.
    • Discuss the process of containerization. 
    • Identify the compatibility characteristics for different types of cargo. 
    • Outline the different types of containers. 
    • Analyze the way containers are marked during shipping. 
  • Unloading Operations Container Shipping and Systems
  • The container ships are the biggest revolution that almost crippled breakbulk ships that were carrying small parcels of cargo. According to Lloyd’s Register of Shipping, in 1995, the total general cargo of 56.8 million GT. in seaborne world trade, over 37.7 million GT., was carried on container ships. This goes to show the dominance of container ships over general cargo ships in carrying dry packaged cargo.

    The technology in handling containers and its stowage on ships has advanced so much that the cargo loading and unloading time has reduced drastically. A cargo which used to take a week to load and unload now takes just a few hours to handle due to the advances in container handling and stowage technology. This has resulted in a demand for well-trained personnel engaged in the maritime supply chain industry.
  • What is Happening to the Container Fleet?
  • In terms of geography, North America dominates the global container shipping market. This is due to improved transportation services in this region. The U.S. represents the largest market for container shipping followed by Canada in North America. In Europe, Germany, the U.K., Spain, Italy, and France hold the major share of the container shipping market. Asia is expected to witness high growth rates in the next five years, as many companies are constructing manufacturing facilities in this region. The rising number of manufacturing units would result in a significant rise in demand for containers. Improving transportation services are boosting the growth of the container shipping market in this region. Japan, China, and India are expected to be the fastest-growing container shipping markets in Asia.

  • Introduction 
  • Containers are used to transport objects from one place to another. Unlike conventional shipping, container shipping uses containers of various standard sizes—20 foot (6.09 m), 40 foot (12.18 m), 45 foot (13.7 m), 48 foot (14.6 m), and 53 foot (16.15 m)—to load, transport, and unload goods or objects. 

    As a result, containers can be moved by trains, ships and trucks. Most commonly and important container sizes are 20-foot and 40-foot lengths. The 20-foot container is generally referred to as a Twenty-foot Equivalent Unit (TEU) and the 40-foot container is known as the Forty-foot Equivalent Unit (FEU).

Unlike conventional shipping, container shipping uses containers of various standard sizes—20 foot (6.09 m), 40 foot (12.18 m), 45 foot (13.7 m), 48 foot (14.6 m), and 53 foot (16.15 m)—to load, transport, and unload goods or objects. 

    As a result, containers can be moved by trains, ships and trucks. Most commonly and important container sizes are 20-foot and 40-foot lengths. The 20-foot container is generally referred to as a Twenty-foot Equivalent Unit (TEU) and the 40-foot container is known as the Forty-foot Equivalent Unit (FEU).

  • Before Loading Reefer Containers
  • Procedures to be followed prior loading reefer containers are as below:
    • Vessels should always carry basic reefer spare parts, suitable tools and repair manuals specifically relating to the type(s) of reefer units. These are required so that the reefer technician can effect emergency repairs during the voyage if necessary. There are several types of reefer units in general use, one must note that each have their own repair maintenance characteristics
    • The ship’s crew should make certain that reefer container spares provided for are of the correct type and quantity before loading commences
    • Before loading commences crew should reconfirm that the vessel’s reefer plugs are compatible with the reefer containers planned for shipment
    • A number of reefer extension leads should be carried as a precaution against the failure of individual plugs
    • There have been reefer containers losses have because of incorrect temperature settings sometimes caused because of an incorrect understanding of the fahrenheit and celsius temperature scales and between plus and minus temperatures. Therefore great care should be exercised to ensure that carriage temperatures are correctly set as soon as containers are placed on board. Any discrepancy between container settings as received and bill of lading instructions should be reported immediately

  • Bay Number System
  • The bay-row-tier system is a numbering format for the arrangement of containers on a container vessel. In this numbering system, the bay is specified first, then the row (transverse stow direction) and finally the container tier, which runs from bottom to top.

    According to this principle, bays are the container blocks in the fore and aft direction, rows are in the transverse direction and tiers are the vertical layers. A container bay is a container stowage compartment space that is numbered from forward to aft. The number of bays will depend on the size the size of the ship. Bays could be numbered from say 01 to 40 where Bay 01 is the first bay, forward while Bay 40 is the last one at the stern.

    Odd numbered bays (1,3,5, etc.) will mean that it is a 20’ stow. An even numbered bay (2, 6, etc.) will mean that it is a 40’ stow. (note in this regard bays 1 & 3 combine to form bay 2, two twenty foot bays form one 40 foot bay, 5 & 7 will combine to form bay 6 and so on)

  • Lesson Summary
    • Containerization is a shipping process. It allows the consolidation of smaller parcels, bags, bundles, bales, or crates of cargo into standardized cargo units that facilitate their expeditious movement.
    • The full benefit of containerization stems from the ability to exchange the load units from one mode to the others at various nodes such as seaports and intermodal terminals. 
    • If goods are to be stowed together when packing a container, Goods may react with one another and possibly with their environment. These properties of products must be taken into account, else may result in quality degradation and damage.
    • The container shipping industry uses approved marine ISO containers which come typically in lengths of 20 (TEU) and 40 (FEU) ft.
    • Containers are used to transport objects from one place to another. Unlike conventional shipping, container shipping uses containers of various standard sizes—20 foot (6.09 m), 40 foot (12.18 m), 45 foot (13.7 m), 48 foot (14.6 m), and 53 foot (16.15 m)—to load, transport, and unload goods or objects.
    • Typical ISO (International Standards Organization) shipping containers are manufactured with identical size specifications in terms of exterior height, exterior width, and exterior length. 
    • The bay-row-tier system is a numbering format for the arrangement of containers on a container vessel. In this numbering system, the bay is specified first, then the row (transverse stow direction) and finally the container tier, which runs from bottom to top.
    • A container bay is a container stowage compartment space that is numbered from forward to aft. The number of bays will depend on the size of the ship.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the importance of liner services. 
    • Outline the different types of liner ships used in shipping. 
    • Identify some liner service strategies and how they are applied. 
    • Outline the multi-trade strategies used in shipping today. 
    • Discuss some liner shipping regulations. 
    • Discuss the impact of mega container ships in shipping. 
  • Introduction 
  • A liner service is a fleet of ships, with a common ownership or management, which provide a fixed service, at regular intervals, between named ports, and offer transport to any goods in the catchment area served by those ports and ready for transit by their sailing dates. A fixed itinerary, inclusion in a regular service, and the obligation to accept cargo from all comers and to sail, whether filled or not, on the date fixed by a published schedule are what distinguish the liner from the tramp. (A short history of the worlds shipping industry, Fayle)
  • A combination of fixed prices and inflexible compacity leaves liner companies with a pricing problem which has dominated the industry since it started. The conference system, developed in the mid 1870's, was the industries first attempt to deal with the pricing problem. The liner companies were in a much better position to form a cartel to fix rates so that in the words of John Sawyer, "The companies may not ruin eachother". By the early 1970's there were more than 360 conferences with memberships from 2-40 shipping lines.

    Liner shipping companies, referred to as liner operators, are the key players in facilitating international container movements. They provide regular, reliable shipping services for shippers big or small at predictable freight rates. This particular section will focus on liner operators, container ship types, liner strategies, and the current regulatory environment. The graph given shows the top 10 liner operators as of Jan 2006.

A fixed itinerary, inclusion in a regular service, and the obligation to accept cargo from all comers and to sail, whether filled or not, on the date fixed by a published schedule are what distinguish the liner from the tramp. (A short history of the worlds shipping industry, Fayle)
  • A combination of fixed prices and inflexible compacity leaves liner companies with a pricing problem which has dominated the industry since it started. The conference system, developed in the mid 1870's, was the industries first attempt to deal with the pricing problem. The liner companies were in a much better position to form a cartel to fix rates so that in the words of John Sawyer, "The companies may not ruin eachother". By the early 1970's there were more than 360 conferences with memberships from 2-40 shipping lines.

    Liner shipping companies, referred to as liner operators, are the key players in facilitating international container movements. They provide regular, reliable shipping services for shippers big or small at predictable freight rates. This particular section will focus on liner operators, container ship types, liner strategies, and the current regulatory environment. The graph given shows the top 10 liner operators as of Jan 2006.

  • Mega Container Ships and their Costs
  • Ever bigger container ships inspire awe and fascination, and are one of the hottest topics in maritime transport. 

    They are also a headache for ports and terminals – mainly because of their vast size. Now at up to 400 metres long, these ships are longer than Eiffel Tower (301 metres).

    This size increase has been exponential; ships doubled in volume in 20 years between 1975 and 1995, and then almost doubled again in the following decade, doubling yet again between 2005 and 2015. 

    And it is not over yet. Plans are afoot to continue increase size to 21100 TEU by 2018.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Liner service is a fleet of ships, with common ownership or management, which provide a fixed service, at regular intervals, between named ports, and offer transport to any goods in the catchment area served by those ports and ready for transit by their sailing dates.
    • A fixed itinerary, inclusion in regular service, and the obligation to accept cargo from all comers and to sail, whether filled or not, on the date fixed by a published schedule are what distinguish the liner from the tramp.
    • Liner shipping companies, referred to as liner operators, are the key players in facilitating international container movements.
    • The ships used in the liner sector have changed radically from the traditional liner ships of the WWII era to the highly sophisticated fully cellular container ships of today. 
    • The various multi-trade strategies used today are:
      - Parallel linkages
      - Non-parallel linkages
      - Network linkages
    • Economic regulation has been a key aspect of liner shipping right from its formative years because of the role of what are referred to as liner conferences, also referred to as liner cartels.
    • Container ships are the work-horses of the globalized economy: although they represent only one-eighth of the total world fleet they are essential for the transport of consumer goods around the world.
